title: 20 Minutes With: Marrakech-Based Carpet and Homeware Dealer Ismail Zarib
text:
Text size

Best known for its carpets—which range from vintage Berber to contemporary in-house designs—Moroccan home design company Soufiane Zarib supplies for stores across the U.S., Europe, and Australia, including ABC Carpet & Home and Lillian August in New York, with private clients such as models Iman and Bethann Hardison. The firm also designed original pieces for the Christian Dior fashion show in Marrakech last spring.

A family business now in its third generation, the owners, cousins Soufiane and Ismail Zarib, turned an old riad—a traditional Moroccan courtyard home—in the city’s market district into a store with an international reputation, thanks to its focus on expertly sourced vintage rugs.

Four years ago, the company opened a large showroom in the Medina. Today the firm produces its own carpets, as well as clothing, accessories, and furniture. Here, you’ll find arguably the best rugs in Marrakech, and in a modern, haggle-free environment. “We like to give people a serious price, and that’s it,” says the 30-year-old Ismail Zarib. “We do this because we pay more for them.”

Next month, Soufiane Zarib will open a clubhouse next door to the showroom, where international guests will be invited to exclusive dinners and performances. The space will also be used to showcase items of the company’s non-carpet business, with collaborations with local artists exhibited in the space.

“We want to move away from the bazaar mentality,” Zarib says. “Our main business is carpets, but we don’t want to be just a carpet dealer.”

PENTA : Tell me the company’s backstory. What sets you apart from the hundreds of other carpet dealers in the souk?

Ismail Zarib: It’s a family business. My grandfather used to sell old djellaba [long, unisex robes]. My uncle, which is Soufiane’s father, used to sell carpets, but only to Moroccan people. He used to be very traditional.

We moved to [the flagship showroom] four years ago. Before that we were in the market, in the souk. We were the first people to take an old riad and turn it into a shop… When we came to this place, we built it ourselves, designed it ourselves.

What happened was, when we started visiting trade shows, it opened our eyes to a different world of carpet business. We started to produce the carpet by ourselves. We started to hire the women [carpet weavers; virtually all carpet weavers in Morocco are women], we started to buy the wool, we buy the colors, we give them the design we want. At the beginning it was very difficult, but then later they started understanding what we want. It took us three to four years of working with them until we got to what we want exactly.

All the carpets we produce ourselves, we want them to be one-of-a-kind. We don’t want to do mass production.

Soufiane Zarib's showroom in Marrakech. Michael Magers

What percentage of carpets that you sell are vintage, and what percentage are of your own design?

Fifteen years [ago] everyone wanted to have vintage carpets. But the problem with the vintage carpets…[is] you have to go through a hundred carpets, and you’d pick only five or 10 pieces that are amazing—by colors, by design, by quality. This is what we buy.

But now they are everywhere. So we still buy the vintage pieces, but only the really, really special ones... It used to be we would sell 90% vintage and 10% new ones. Now it’s almost the opposite. People buy 95% new carpet, and 5% and 10% vintage carpet.

How many carpets do you have in your collection, total?

We have almost 50,000 or 60,000 vintage carpets in stock. We know that [many of them] are not sellable right now, but believe that one day people will come back to it. They keep going up in value.

What do you look for when you’re sourcing vintage rugs?

The design is the most important thing you should see in the carpet. Then the quality comes second. Then the condition of the carpet.

Our carpets are really expensive, because we go with the higher quality of the wool. Because there’s many, many, many kids of different type of the wool.

What’s the price range?

For the vintage ones, the price is up or down…it depends on quality. For the new ones, there’s a balance. The prices for lower quality, 10 feet by 14 feet, it’s going to cost you US$1,000. Very good quality will cost you US$3,000-US$3,500. It’s not going to go over that, it’s not going to go lower than that. In between, there’s always something.

You see a lot about Moroccan carpets recently. Why is that? Is it because they look good on Instagram?

Moroccan carpets are [growing in popularity] in the last 10 years because now there’s a community of people who come to Morocco—especially French people, Spanish people, some American people—they come to Morocco, and most of them, they create an account on Instagram. So what they do, they go to shops, they take several pictures, and they say, ‘OK, this carpet, it’s mine. I want to sell it.’ Everyone wants to do this now.

Is traditional carpet weaving a dying trade in Morocco?

The new generation—kids—they don’t work in carpets… [But for the women in the villages] it creates jobs. We create jobs for these people. Sometimes I go to the places and I found women who have 21, 22, 23 years experience making carpets. And this is a good thing, because she’s making a living now from what she’s doing. Before she used to make it just for her house. Who was going to pay her?

Also, she’s creating. I give her three or four colors, and I tell her you can do something from your imagination. And sometimes you end up having a nice piece, and this is what we want. We want them to be more creative. We don’t want them to live [the same way] their grandparents or parents used to live.
description: The co-owner of the firm Soufiane Zarib on the enduring appeal of Moroccan design
